episodes.title: How QAnon and Epstein blew up the justice system | If You're Listening
episodes.description:
When news first broke of a billionaire sex offender with a private island… the story didn’t erupt through traditional media. Instead it circulated through online message boards like 4chan. 
What began as internet trolling and fragmented rumor became fuel for something much bigger. The Epstein case fed directly into the rise of QAnon, a conspiracy movement built on the belief that a hidden elite was operating above the law. 
Now, after years of pressure and public obsession, millions of Epstein-related documents have been released by the U.S. government. 
The Epstein Files have exposed networks, associations, and uncomfortable truths. But instead of restoring trust in institutions, they’ve underscored how fragile that trust has become.
 
Catch up on past If You're Listening episode's on Jeffrey Epstein: 

Was Jeffrey Epstein a Mossad agent?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=toqY9NIADrY

Are the MAGA podcasters right about Epstein? | If You're Listening
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6zzWn4_Rrac

episodes.description:
Trump calls for Americans to “move on” as Democrats pledge to fight an Epstein files “cover-up”. Also, the Trump family crypto scandal the world has hardly noticed, and the President’s rare backdown on his racist Obama post.

episodes.title: New documents from the Epstein files cause shockwaves around the world | 7.30
episodes.description:
Millions more documents relating to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein were released by the US Department of Justice last week and observers are still poring over them.

The story the files tell is one of base corruption that stains all it touches. But Epstein was also a notorious liar and blackmailer, so the fact that he mentioned someone in his communications doesn't mean that they were part of his network.

7.30’s Alysia Thomas Sam reports.

episodes.title: Escaping the religious ‘cult’ tied to big business | Four Corners Documentary
episodes.description:
In the streets of suburban Sydney lies the spiritual headquarters of the Plymouth Brethren Christian Church — a secretive, ultra-wealthy organisation whose $22 billion business empire stretches around the globe.  

Former members and even the Australian Prime Minister have accused the religious group, once known as the Exclusive Brethren, of operating like a cult, while its leader Bruce Hales and his family live in luxury, at the centre of a network of thousands of companies worldwide.  

This week on Four Corners, former members tell reporter Louise Milligan about the psychological manipulation, surveillance, and threats the church allegedly uses against them, as well as attempts to intimidate them and buy their silence.  

Big Brethren charts how some companies that support the church have amassed billions and are now under scrutiny from the Australian Taxation Office.   

Whistleblowers also reveal the group’s attempts at political penetration, including covert election campaigning, despite members traditionally being discouraged from voting. 

Note: In most cases, our captions are auto-generated.

#ABCNewsIndepth #ABCNewsAustralia

episodes.title: The Saints on trial: How a religious cult let a child die | Compass
episodes.description:
As 8-year-old diabetic Elizabeth Struhs lay dying in her home in Toowoomba, her parents and other members of the religious cult The Saints gathered around her and sang. 
They withheld her life-saving insulin medication, believing God would heal her.  
But Elizabeth died, and The Saints members are now in jail for manslaughter. 
In this confronting documentary, award-winning journalist Suzanne Smith enters their world and talks to their families and former cult members.

For The Cult of The Saints and more stories about our ethics, spirituality and beliefs, watch ABC Compass on iview. 

00:00 - The Cult of The Saints  
02:00 – Inside the Toowoomba Pentecostal cult
02:56 – The death of eight-year-old diabetic, Elizabeth Struhs
04:24 -- Maria Esguerra, psychologist and survivor of The Children of God cult
05:58 – Cameron Schoenfisch on his son, Lachlan’s, part in the manslaughter of Elizabeth Struhs
09:42 – Who is The Saints leader, Brendan Stephens?
12:40 – Police interviews with members of The Saints cult
16:50 – Who is Elizabeth Struhs’s mother, Kerrie Struhs?
19:40 – The rise of Pentecostalism in Toowoomba

episodes.title: Members of religious sect sentenced to jail for the manslaughter of Elizabeth Struhs | 7.30
episodes.description:
A Brisbane judge today sentenced 14 members of the extreme religious sect called The Saints to jail time after an eight-year-old diabetic girl died in their care.

Elizabeth Struhs died four days after she was denied insulin. Her mother and father were part of the group, which didn't believe in medical treatment.

In her first interview since the trial, Elizabeth's older sister Jayde has spoken to 7.30's Alexandra Blucher. Produced by Raveen Hunjan.

Subscribe: https://ab.co/3yqPOZ5   Read more: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-02-26/jayde-struhs-inside-the-saints-elizabeth-struhs-death/104954652

episodes.title: Religious group members found guilty of manslaughter of eight-year-old girl | 7.30
episodes.description:
Fourteen members of a small, extreme religious group called The Saints have been found guilty of the manslaughter of eight-year-old Queensland girl Elizabeth Struhs.

Among the 14 are Elizabeth's parents, who made the catastrophic decision to stop giving her life-saving medication.

7.30’s Alexandra Blucher reports.

episodes.title: Inside the school where 'purity is everything' | Four Corners
episodes.description:
Former students speak out about disturbing practices at their Australian high schools, alleging they were taught false information about sex. 

One private school student says she was told watching porn would cause holes in her brain. Another says students were told getting a lifesaving cancer vaccine would encourage them to be promiscuous. Many say their experiences left them psychologically scarred. 

The schools are connected to the secretive Catholic organisation Opus Dei. 

Here, Four Corners goes inside the little-known world of Opus Dei and investigates its links to senior politicians. 

Chapters:  
0:00 Intro: Secrets and shame 
3:10 ‘It’s about virginity’ 
7:41 ‘Recruitment’ into Opus Dei 
13:20 ‘Don’t be a slut’ 
16:37 Self-mortification 
19:28 Vaccine ‘promotes promiscuity’ 
22:45 Porn ‘causes holes in the brain’ 
29:11 Consent education 
32:39 Homosexual acts ‘a sin’ 
36:26 Political links 
40:24 Physical relationship  
 
This Four Corners documentary was originally broadcast as ‘Purity’ on January 30, 2023, on ABC TV and ABC iview. 

Read more about the story here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2023-01-30/inside-sydney-opus-dei-affiliated-private-schools/101777060    

Full statements from Opus Dei Australia and the Pared Foundation can be found on the Four Corners website: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2023-02-15/purity:-an-education-in-opus-dei/101979020  

Update: Dominic Perrottet stepped down as New South Wales Liberal leader after losing the state election in March 2023.

episodes.title: Escaping Jehovah's Witnesses: Inside the dangerous world of a brutal religion | Four Corners
episodes.description:
Former Jehovah's Witnesses are fighting back against a religion that failed them. They know they'll lose their loved ones for doing so.
 
Subscribe: https://www.youtube.com/c/abcnewsindepth
 
Few know the extreme nature of the beliefs of the Jehovah's Witnesses, a religious group which boasts eight million followers in multiple nations.
 
They take a strict interpretation of the Bible and predicted the world would meet its ‘wicked end’ in 1914, 1925 and 1975.
 
A US-based Governing Body of eight men sits at the pinnacle of the Jehovah’s Witnesses organisation. Witnesses believe these men are anointed as the voice of God on Earth. 
 
Former members reveal the secretive practices used to instil fear and maintain discipline among followers.
 
With strict rules governing every aspect of their lives, these former Witnesses say the organisation is controlling and dangerous.
 
They say it's time to hold the Jehovah's Witnesses to account.
